   - Started on treatment for PCP- [**Name10 (NameIs) 1369**] and prednisone

   for PCP
   [**11-3**] Urine culture pending, NGTD
   Radiology Studies:
   [**11-3**] High resolution chest CT:
   1. Recent changes over four days documented by conventional chest
   radiographs
   indicate that at least some of the reticular and ground-glass
   abnormalities in
   the lungs, which have worsened since [**10-29**] are pulmonary edema.
   The
   progression of the same abnormalities between [**10-9**] and [**10-29**] could
   be due to some component of interstitial lung disease, which was
   clearly
   present on the earliest examination.
   2. Persistent pulmonary arterial hypertension and global cardiomegaly.
   Severe
   coronary atherosclerotic calcification. Aortic valvular calcification
   of
   uncertain significance.
   3. Large thyroid cysts or nodules. Ultrasound examination recommended
   if not
   already obtained.
   For subsequent evaluation of the progression of pulmonary edema or
   interstitial lung disease, conventional radiograph should be employed
   as a
   first step.
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continued to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. This morning he was transitioned to a high-flow mask
   and is impoved on that. Read of high resolution chest CT yesterday was
   suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial
   lung disease, however overall picture is more consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP in setting of his interstitial lung disease.
   Will not purse further diuresis given he overall appears euvolemic and
   had hypotension after diuresis yesterday.  We are continuing treatment
   for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term steroid use
   and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is lymphangitic
   spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of levofloxacin
   (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Will hold off PFTs as not likely to be helpful in setting of acute
   decompensation.
   - ICU fellow [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 955**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 90**] discussed case with patient
s outpatient
   pulmonologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**] reported that the patient had
   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. This episode was likely secondary to his diruesis after
   the lasix he received. His borderline low BP remains likely
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
will try to reach patient
   primary oncologist today to further discuss his prognosis to help
   further discuss goals of care and how aggressively to further work up
   and treat his pulmonary process.
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain, appreciate assistance. Tube is in place
   mainly for imaging purposes and will be taken out in future.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. Glargine was increased last night to 40 units.
   - Given ability to improve control while patient remains in ICU, will
   initiated insulin gtt.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Diabetic, cardiac
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin gtt.
   Lines:
   PIVs x2
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  Heparin SQ
   Stress ulcer:  On PPI for hx GERD as well.
   VAP:  N/A
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code currently, patient still thinking over
   options
will try to re-address with wife today, oncologist.
   Disposition: ICU until respiratory status improved.

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia and feeling well but remaining hypoxic. He has been treated for PCP with prednisone and IV antibiotics, and his high-resolution chest CT scan shows worsening reticular and ground-glass abnormalities, pulmonary arterial hypertension, and global cardiomegaly.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's high-resolution chest CT scan shows evidence of pulmonary edema, which can worsen his respiratory status and increase his risk of respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient has been treated for PCP, but he may still have an underlying infection that is not responding to treatment. This could lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and diastolic heart failure, which increases his risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiac arrest.
4. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level has decreased to 8.5 g/dL, which may be due to chronic disease, bleeding, or other causes. Anemia can worsen his overall condition and increase his risk of complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which may be due to a variety of causes including infection, cardiac complications, or medication side effects. Hypotension can worsen his condition and increase his risk of complications.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.3 mg/dL, which may be due to acute kidney injury or other causes. Acute kidney injury can worsen his condition and increase his risk of complications.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he may require mechanical ventilation to support his breathing. Respiratory failure can worsen his condition and increase his risk of complications.

Overall, the patient is at high risk of complications due to his underlying medical conditions and the severity of his illness. Close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

* [**Name10 (NameIs) 1369**] for Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

The patient's plan includes:

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Infection control issues due to prolonged ICU stay and use of invasive devices.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continues to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. High resolution chest CT yesterday was suspicious
   for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial lung disease.
   It is still likely that the cause of his hypoxia is likely
   multifactorial due to possible pulmonary infection (purlent sputum,
   fevers), ILD exacerbation in setting of prednisone being tapered, and
   acute diastolic CHF exacerbation.
   .
   He continues to appear rather euvolemic on exam. We are continuing
   treatment for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term
   steroid use and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is
   lymphangitic spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of
   levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Incentive Spirometry
   - Creatinine bumped since yesterday, but given CT appearance, will
   discuss trial of lasix to see if patient is able to come off
   non-rebreather
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. The etiology is unclear, but could be likely be
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**]
   - Diuresis as needed for respiratory state and tolerated by blood
   pressure.
   - Stress dose steroids given this morning given history of use and
   recent taper.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR pending from this morning.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Discussing possible additional diuresis today.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection.
   - Will plan to increase PM glargine and humalog sliding scale.
   .
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   .
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia.
   .
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continues to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. High resolution chest CT yesterday was suspicious
   for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial lung disease.
   It is still likely that the cause of his hypoxia is likely
   multifactorial due to possible pulmonary infection (purlent sputum,
   fevers), ILD exacerbation in setting of prednisone being tapered, and
   acute diastolic CHF exacerbation.
   .
   He continues to appear rather euvolemic on exam. We are continuing
   treatment for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term
   steroid use and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is
   lymphangitic spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of
   levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated [**Month/Year (2) **] IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Incentive Spirometry
   - Creatinine bumped since yesterday, but given CT appearance, will
   discuss trial of lasix to see if patient is able to come off
   non-rebreather
   .
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   .
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. The etiology is unclear, but could be likely be
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**]
   - Diuresis as needed for respiratory state and tolerated by blood
   pressure.
   - Stress dose steroids given this morning given history of use and
   recent taper.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   .
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain.
   .
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   .
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR pending from this morning.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   .
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Discussing possible additional diuresis today.
   .
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   .
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   .
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection.
   - Will plan to increase PM glargine and humalog sliding scale.
   .

Based on the progress note, the patient's current condition is complex and multifaceted. The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic CHF, CAD, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and has been treated with antibiotics, steroids, and other medications.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.1°C (100.6°F)
* Heart rate: 78 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 121/57 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 19 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%
* SpO2: 97%

The patient's lab results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.4 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 434 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 25 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+ 133 mmol/L, K+ 4.4 mmol/L, Cl- 98 mmol/L
* Glucose: 301 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.7 mmol/L
* Troponin T: 0.02 ng/mL

The patient's radiology studies show:

* High-resolution chest CT: Reticular and ground-glass abnormalities have worsened, with pulmonary arterial hypertension and global cardiomegaly.
* Echocardiogram: Not available.

The patient's medical history and current conditions include:

* Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia is likely multifactorial, with possible causes including pulmonary infection, ILD exacerbation, and acute diastolic CHF exacerbation.
* Fever and leukocytosis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis have resolved, but he is still at risk for infection.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is unclear, but may be due to intravascular depletion, adrenal insufficiency, or diabetic autonomic dysfunction.
* CAD/NSTEMI: The patient has a history of CAD and NSTEMI, and is currently receiving medical management.
* Acute diastolic CHF: The patient's acute diastolic CHF is likely due to NSTEMI or infection, and he is currently clinically euvolemic.
* ARF: The patient's creatinine has bumped up to 1.3 mg/dL, and he is at risk for further kidney damage.
* Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan: The patient's thyroid is heterogeneous on CT scan, and an ultrasound may be necessary to further characterize.
* Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic disease, and he is being treated with iron supplements.
* DM2: The patient's DM2 is being treated with insulin and sliding scale.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing antibiotics and steroids for PCP
* Monitoring for infection and adjusting antibiotics as necessary
* Continuing diuresis as necessary for respiratory state
* Considering trial of lasix to see if patient can come off non-rebreather
* Monitoring for hypotension and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Continuing cardiac and diabetic diet
* Repleting electrolytes as necessary
* Communicating with patient's wife and son.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Pneumonia or other infections
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Acute kidney injury (AKI)
* Cardiac arrhythmias or failure
* Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
* Hypoglycemia
* Hypotension or shock
* Sepsis
* Thrombosis or embolism
* Thyroid dysfunction.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently receiving oxygen therapy.

The patient's medical conditions and laboratory results suggest potential complications, including:

1. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level is 21.9 g/dL, which is low. The etiology of anemia is unclear, and the patient is being transfused with blood.
2. Hypoxia: The patient is still hypoxic, despite being on 100% oxygen therapy. The cause of hypoxia is multifactorial, including anemia, interstitial lung disease, and potential atypical infection or PCP.
3. Infection: The patient is being treated empirically for PCP, and the sputum sample was negative. However, the patient has a history of long-term steroid use, which increases the risk of infection.
4. Cardiovascular disease: The patient has a history of NSTEMI, and his cardiac enzymes are elevated. He is being treated with anticoagulation therapy and has a prophylactic heparin infusion.
5. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's blood glucose levels have been running high, and he has been treated with insulin.
6. Fluid imbalance: The patient has a fluid imbalance, with a positive fluid balance of 521 mL over the past 24 hours.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, and his oxygen saturation is 97%.

The patient's medications include:

1. Prednisone: 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days
2. Bactrim IV: 3 weeks of empiric therapy for PCP
3. Vancomycin: 2 weeks of empiric therapy for hospital-acquired pneumonia
4. Zosyn: 2 weeks of empiric therapy for hospital-acquired pneumonia
5. Insulin: Glargine was increased to 40 units last night, and the patient is receiving insulin therapy
6. Heparin: Prophylactic infusion for DVT prophylaxis

The patient's laboratory results include:

1. Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 13.4, Hct 21.9, Platelet count 61
2. Blood chemistry: Creatinine 1.2, BUN 27, Glucose 128
3. Electrolytes: Sodium 134, Potassium 4.0, Chloride 25
4. Coagulation studies: PT 13.4, PTT 27.2, INR 1.2

The patient's radiology results include:

1. Chest CT: Suspicious for pulmonary edema in the setting of interstitial lung disease
2. Abdominal CT: Heterogeneous thyroid nodule

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued oxygen therapy
2. Empiric therapy for PCP
3. Antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia
4. Insulin therapy for diabetic ketoacidosis
5. Fluid management to address fluid imbalance
6. Monitoring for infection and sepsis
7. Follow-up with oncology team to discuss prognosis and goals of care

   LDH:485 IU/L, Ca++:8.8 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:2.8 mg/dL
   Fluid analysis / Other labs: - Hct baseline high 20s
   Microbiology: [**2138-11-4**] sputum poor sample.
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   # Hypoxia
 Patient continued to be on non-rebreather for the better
   part of yesterday. This morning he was transitioned to a high-flow mask
   and is impoved on that. Read of high resolution chest CT yesterday was
   suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of underlying interstitial
   lung disease, however overall picture is more consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP in setting of his interstitial lung disease.
   Will not purse further diuresis given he overall appears euvolemic and
   had hypotension after diuresis yesterday.  We are continuing treatment
   for PCP in the setting of his elevated LDH and long-term steroid use
   and CT that could be consistent with this.  Less likely is lymphangitic
   spread of carcinoma.- Patient just completed 7 days of levofloxacin
   (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - Ordered induced sputum culture for PCP stain as well, given that the
   only negative PCP stain is from a sample that was contaminated.
   Currently patient appears too tenuous to bronch at present.
   - Initiate steroid treatment for PCP yesterday, which will also treat
   his intersitial lung disease, if this is playing role. Plan will be for
   prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 = [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days,
   then 20 mg for 11 days. Initiated Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]) for PCP
   treatment as well.
   - Initiated vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-4**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Will hold off PFTs as not likely to be helpful in setting of acute
   decompensation.
   - ICU fellow [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 955**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 90**] discussed case with patient
s outpatient
   pulmonologist, Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]. Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**] reported that the patient had
   presented several years ago and had diffuse changes on CT (ground
   glass, fibrosis). The patient was initially treated with high dose
   steroids, then quickly tapered down to maintance dose (2.5-10 mg per
   reports).  A bronchosocpy was never completed per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5568**]
s report.
   This would likely be helpful for additional work up, but patient
   remains too tenuous to bronch at present.
   # Fever, leukocytosis: Resolved from yesterday, when there had been
   concern for infection in setting of low grade temp and leukocytosis.
   Continuing to monitor for infection (possible sources including urinary
   given foley, lung given hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - Will follow up culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also
   cover gram negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   # Hypotension
 Yesterday had transient hypotension (80
s), which was
   asymptomatic. This episode was likely secondary to his diruesis after
   the lasix he received. His borderline low BP remains likely
   multifactorial with differential diagnosis including intravascularly
   depleted vs adrenal insufficiency in setting of long term steroid use
   vs diabetic autonomic dysfunction. Yesterday concern was for possibly
   brewing sepsis, but resolved today. Will consider tolerating if
   mentating, making urine, asymptomatic and MAP >55-60.
   - Goal SBP >100
   - AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril given recent creatinine bump.
   - If possible, once more stable, will consider addition of low dose
   metoprolol given recent NSTEMI if tolerated by bp
   # Cholangio CA, biliary stricture - Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Follow-up as outpatient with oncology
will try to reach patient
   primary oncologist today to further discuss his prognosis to help
   further discuss goals of care and how aggressively to further work up
   and treat his pulmonary process.
   - Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team will see patient today to help guide
   recommendations for drain, appreciate assistance. Tube is in place
   mainly for imaging purposes and will be taken out in future.
   # CAD/NSTEMI - NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**],
   trending down since, prior ECG changes with diffuse precordial T wave
   inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology had been following, recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   # Acute diastolic CHF - Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection,
   now likely clinically euvolemic. BNP drawn with AM labs.
   - Will discuss possible trial of diuresis today, however creatinine did
   bump from 1.1 to 1.3 overnight.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Last echo as noted above.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   # ARF- This morning creatinine 1.3, which is a bump from yesterday
   1.1. Previously had bumpted to 1.4, likely secondary to diuresis
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   # Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan - Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize, once more stable or as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   # Anemia: HCT dipped down today to 25. Over last weeks to month, has
   been 26-29. Iron Studies indicative of Anemia of Chronic Disease given
   advanced ca; no evidence of acute bleeding.
   - Folate, TSH, B-12 all within normal limits.
   - Will check PM HCT to ensure it is stable.
   # DM2: FSBG have been running high since last night (300
s-400
   Suspect secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. Glargine was increased last night to 40 units.
   - Given ability to improve control while patient remains in ICU, will
   initiated insulin gtt.
   #. FEN - Cardiac, diabetic diet. Will replete electrolytes as needed.
   #. Communication - Wife, [**Name (NI) 2856**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5547**], and son [**Name (NI) 2667**] [**Name (NI) **]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5548**]

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was recently diagnosed with pulmonary edema and is being treated for possible PCP infection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T: 36.6°C, HR: 74 bpm, BP: 111/50 mmHg, RR: 22 breaths/min, SpO2: 97%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous pressure (CVP) not measured
* Fluid balance: Total fluid input 3,451 mL, total fluid output 2,930 mL, with a balance of 521 mL
* Respiratory support: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) with oxygen saturation of 97%
* Laboratory results:
	+ WBC: 13.4 K/μL
	+ Hct: 29.2%
	+ Platelets: 61 K/μL
	+ Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
	+ Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
	+ LDH: 485 IU/L
	+ Calcium: 8.8 mg/dL
	+ Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
	+ Phosphorus: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Insulin glargine
* Prednisone
* Bactrim
* Vancomycin
* Zosyn
* Heparin sodium
* Aspirin
* Low-dose beta-blocker
* Statin
* Plavix

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue treatment for PCP infection with prednisone and Bactrim
* Monitor for signs of infection, including fever, leukocytosis, and changes in mental status
* Continue respiratory support with HFNC and oxygen therapy
* Monitor for signs of hypotension and adjust fluid management as needed
* Consider trial of diuresis to manage fluid overload
* Monitor for signs of cardiac dysfunction and adjust medication regimen as needed
* Continue to monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust treatment plan accordingly

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to underlying infections
* Cardiac dysfunction or heart failure due to underlying coronary artery disease or diastolic congestive heart failure
* Respiratory failure due to underlying interstitial lung disease or pulmonary edema
* Kidney injury or acute kidney injury due to underlying diabetes or fluid overload
* Electrolyte imbalances due to underlying kidney disease or fluid overload
* Thrombocytopenia or bleeding due to underlying liver disease or coagulopathy

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted with hypoxemic respiratory failure and is currently being treated in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), heart rate of 78 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/62 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 95%. His respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, anemia, and elevated creatinine levels. His liver function tests are slightly elevated, and his electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medical plan includes treatment for respiratory failure, which is likely due to infection or underlying ILD. He is being treated with antibiotics, corticosteroids, and diuretics. His anemia is being managed with transfusions and monitoring of hemolysis labs. His diabetes is being managed with insulin and sliding scale.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state and the presence of a central venous catheter.
2. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and bleeding disorder may increase his risk of bleeding.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but he may be at risk for further deterioration.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's CHF and recent NSTEMI may increase his risk of cardiac complications.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are slightly elevated, which may indicate liver dysfunction.
6. Renal insufficiency: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, which may indicate renal insufficiency.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's neurological status is stable, but he may be at risk for further deterioration.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely.
2. Adjust the patient's treatment plan as necessary based on his response to therapy.
3. Consider adding antibiotics to the patient's treatment plan if his respiratory status deteriorates.
4. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and consider transfusions as necessary.
5. Consider adding medications to manage the patient's liver dysfunction and renal insufficiency.
6. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider adding medications to manage any neurological complications that may arise.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU, with a poor prognosis recognized by both the patient and their daughter. The patient has been transfused with one unit of blood and has received various medications, including antibiotics, insulin, and diuretics. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 117/61 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an oxygen saturation of 92% and a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate levels may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's decreased hemoglobin and elevated lactate levels may indicate AKI, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 92% may indicate the presence of respiratory failure, which can lead to hypoxia and further complications.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's elevated blood pressure and decreased hemoglobin may indicate the presence of cardiovascular complications, such as hypertension and anemia.
5. Infection: The patient's contaminated sputum culture and lack of growth in blood cultures may indicate the presence of an infection, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
6. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's poor appetite and lack of enteral nutrition may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
7. Stress Ulceration: The patient's use of steroids and antibiotics may increase the risk of stress ulceration, which can lead to bleeding and further complications.
8. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient's use of heparin prophylaxis may indicate the presence of DVT, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with a poor prognosis, and further monitoring and management are necessary to address the potential medical complications listed above.

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   Hypoxia:  Patient remains on 100% high-flow mask. Subjectively he feels
   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], had [**Month/Year (2) 5604**] prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 =
   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous
   currently, and bronchoscopy would likely lead to intubation, and
   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still
   remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis. Maybe hemolysis,
   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   Leukocytosis: In setting of steroids, stable. Continuing to monitor for
   infection (possible sources including urinary given foley, lung given
   hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - f/u culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also cover gram
   negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture: Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Appreciate oncology input re: prognosis to help further discuss goals
   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary
   process.
   - Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes
   and will be taken out in future. Appreciate input
   CAD/NSTEMI: NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], prior ECG
   changes with diffuse precordial T wave inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology imput appreciated: recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now
   likely clinically euvolemic. No RV pathology in recent ECHO from last
   week.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   ARF: Resolved. Creatinine 1.1, from 1.3 yesterday, highest had been 1.4
   in setting of diuresis .
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan: Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   DM2: FSBG have been running high since transfer up to 300-400. Suspect
   secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. FSBG was slightly low yesterday and this AM, so [**Month/Year (2) 3973**] was

   with increased steroid dose, this does not seen to be a problem
   currently.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] and humalog sliding scale.

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old man with a history of diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic heart failure, and coronary artery disease, was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and treated with antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia and Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP). He received a pulse dose of steroids for possible exacerbation of interstitial lung disease and was continued on empiric PCP treatment. The patient's respiratory status has improved, and he is currently on 100% high-flow mask oxygen.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's CT chest showed suspicious findings for pulmonary edema in the setting of interstitial lung disease, which could worsen his respiratory status.
2. Atypical Infection: The patient's lack of improvement to treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP suggests the possibility of an atypical infection, which could be a source of his continued hypoxia.
3. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia and bloody stool or emesis could be related to hemolysis, which could be caused by Bactrim or cancer-related.
4. Infection: The patient's leukocytosis and continued monitoring for infection could indicate the presence of an infection, which could be a source of his respiratory distress.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient's continued negative fluid balance and lack of evidence of fluid overload on exam suggest that he is not at risk for fluid overload.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's bloody stool or emesis could be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be related to his cholangiocarcinoma or other underlying conditions.
7. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and recent NSTEMI could put him at risk for cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric PCP treatment and monitor for signs of improvement in respiratory status.
2. Consider bronchoscopy or biospy to help guide diagnosis and management of pulmonary process.
3. Monitor for signs of infection, including fever, leukocytosis, and changes in respiratory status.
4. Continue to manage the patient's anemia and bleeding with transfusions and medications as needed.
5. Monitor for signs of fluid overload and adjust fluid management accordingly.
6. Consider ultrasound to further characterize the patient's heterogeneous thyroid nodule.
7. Continue to follow the patient's cardiac and diabetic diet and adjust as needed.
8. Consider repletion of electrolytes as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust oxygen therapy as needed.
10. Consider consulting with oncology and cardiology teams to discuss the patient's prognosis and goals of care.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic CHF, CAD, and recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was transferred to the MICU for hypoxia and is currently on 100% oxygen. He has been treated empirically for PCP and is being monitored for infection. His anemia is unclear in etiology, and he is being transfused for low Hct. His fever, leukocytosis, and hypotension have resolved, but he is still at risk for infection and hypoxia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's CT chest is suspicious for pulmonary edema in setting of ILD, which may worsen his hypoxia.
2. Atypical Infection or PCP: The patient's clinical picture is consistent with an atypical infection or PCP, which may not be responsive to current antibiotics.
3. Hemolysis: The patient's anemia may be due to hemolysis, which could be related to Bactrim, cancer, or an unknown cause.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunocompromised state, urinary catheter, and GI drain.
5. Hypoxia: The patient's hypoxia may worsen due to his underlying lung disease and potential pulmonary edema.
6. Cardiac Complications: The patient's CAD and recent NSTEMI may lead to cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
7. Renal Complications: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to diuresis and potential nephrotoxicity of antibiotics.
8. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's percutaneous drain and potential infection may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or abscess.

Recommendations:

1. Continue empiric treatment for PCP and monitor for signs of infection.
2. Transfuse the patient for low Hct and consider hemolysis labs.
3. Monitor the patient's oxygen saturation and adjust oxygen therapy as needed.
4. Continue to follow the patient's creatinine trend and adjust antibiotic therapy accordingly.
5. Consider ultrasound to further characterize the heterogeneous thyroid lesion.
6. Initiate insulin gtt to improve glycemic control and replete electrolytes as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medication therapy accordingly.
8. Consider stress ulcer prophylaxis and VAP prevention measures.

2. Infection: The patient has a history of PNA and is currently receiving antibiotics. Further testing and evaluation are needed to determine the source and severity of the infection.
3. Hemolysis: The patient's hemoglobin levels have been decreasing, and he has reported bloody stool or emesis. This could indicate hemolysis, which could be related to Bactrim or cancer-related. Further evaluation and monitoring are needed to determine the cause of the hemolysis.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is stable, but the etiology remains unclear. Further evaluation and monitoring are needed to determine the cause of the anemia.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.4, hemoglobin of 7.9 g/dL, and platelet count of 329 K/uL. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 34 and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 12.

The patient's respiratory support includes high-flow nebulization, and their oxygen saturation is 94%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.27, which is slightly acidic. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.2 mEq/L.

The patient's fluid balance is notable, with a total fluid input of 1,800 mL and a total fluid output of 3,035 mL, resulting in a negative fluid balance of -1,235 mL. The patient's urine output is 3,035 mL, and their blood products include 3,035 mL of total output.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.27, which is slightly acidic, indicating potential respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and they have received multiple antibiotics, which may indicate the presence of sepsis.
3. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, which may indicate liver dysfunction.
4. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's potassium level is slightly elevated, which may indicate an electrolyte imbalance.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid balance is negative, which may indicate fluid overload.
6. Bleeding risk: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase their risk of bleeding.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, which may indicate renal failure.

Further monitoring and management of the patient's condition are necessary to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   Hypoxia:  Patient remains on 100% high-flow mask. Subjectively he feels
   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], had [**Month/Year (2) 5604**] prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 =
   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous
   currently, and bronchoscopy would likely lead to intubation, and
   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still
   remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis. Maybe hemolysis,
   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   Leukocytosis: In setting of steroids, stable. Continuing to monitor for
   infection (possible sources including urinary given foley, lung given
   hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - f/u culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also cover gram
   negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture: Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Appreciate oncology input re: prognosis to help further discuss goals
   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary
   process.
   - Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes
   and will be taken out in future. Appreciate input
   CAD/NSTEMI: NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], prior ECG
   changes with diffuse precordial T wave inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology imput appreciated: recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now
   likely clinically euvolemic. No RV pathology in recent ECHO from last

   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.

   - Will continue to follow trend.

   with increased steroid dose, this does not seen to be a problem
   currently.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] and humalog sliding scale.

   Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 79 yo M with PMH DM2, interstitial lung disease,
   diastolic CHF, CAD s/p NSTEMI with recent diagnosis of unresectable
   cholangiocarcinoma s/p CBD excision, cholecystectomy, lymph node bx,
   PTC placement and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy, with no further
   surgical management, transferred to MICU for hypoxia, feeling well but
   remaining hypoxic.
   Hypoxia:  Patient remains on 100% high-flow mask. Subjectively he feels
   his breathing has improved. Prior CT chest suspicious for pulmonary
   edema in setting of ILD, but clinical picture is consistent with an
   atypical infection or PCP. [**Name10 (NameIs) 1204**] lack of improvement to treatment for
   hospital-acquired pneumonia and PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) 5604**] pulse dose steroids
   yesterday to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung
   disease. Will continue to monitor over next 24 hrs, as would expect
   some improvement in oxygen need if steroids are helping. No evidence of
   fluid overload on exam, continues to be negative balance for I/O
   - Patient s/p 7 days of levofloxacin (day 1 = [**2138-10-27**])
   - PCP negative in sputum x1, but poor sputum samples
   - Continue 3 weeks of empiric PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) **]:
   - On [**11-3**], had [**Month/Year (2) 5604**] prednisone 40 mg [**Hospital1 **] for 5 days (day 1 =
   [**11-3**]), 40 mg daily for 5 days, then 20 mg for 11 days.  Yesterday
   started methylprednisolone 250 mg IV TID for three days.
   - Bactrim IV (day 1 = [**11-3**]), today is day 4, was changed to PO
   yesterday to limit fluid loads.
   - Continue vancomycin and zosyn today for hospital acquired PNA (day 1
   = [**11-3**]).
   - Continue with nebulizer tx as needed
   - Continue attempt to wean O2, to keep sat >92%
   - Transfused 1 unit yesterday for low HCT, followed by lasix.
   - Biospy or bronchoscopy would be helpful to help guide diagnosis and
   management, however patient
s respiratory status is too tenuous
   currently, and bronchoscopy would likely lead to intubation, and
   concern is that patient would not be able to be extubated.
   Anemia: Improved this AM after yesterday
s transfusion. Etiology still
   remains unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 59**] reported bloody stool or emesis. Maybe hemolysis,
   bactrim related marrow [**Last Name (LF) 5587**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] be cancer related.
   - Monitoring stook guaiac,
   - Hemolysis labs have not been consistent with hemolysis
   Leukocytosis: In setting of steroids, stable. Continuing to monitor for
   infection (possible sources including urinary given foley, lung given
   hypoxia, and GI given percutaneous drain).
   - f/u culture data, antibiotics as noted above should also cover gram
   negative pathogens from GU/GI tract.
   Hypotension:  Resolved. Hypotension in past has been in setting of
   diuresis. AM cortisol was 24.5 on [**11-2**], on steroids [**Hospital1 **] for above
   reasons.
   - Holding lisinopril and BB given borderline pressures.
   Cholangio CA, biliary stricture: Curative surgery not possible,
   reconstruction with roux-en-y hepaticojejunostomy performed in [**Month (only) 705**]
   [**2138**].
   - Appreciate oncology input re: prognosis to help further discuss goals
   of care and how aggressively to further work up and treat his pulmonary
   process.
   - Per Dr. [**First Name (STitle) 511**]
s team tube is in place mainly for imaging purposes
   and will be taken out in future. Appreciate input
   CAD/NSTEMI: NSTEMI at OSH with troponin peak at 0.76 on [**10-27**], prior ECG
   changes with diffuse precordial T wave inversion, now improved.
   - Cardiology imput appreciated: recommended medical management (ASA,
   low-dose B-Blocker if BP tolerates, Statin, Plavix, holding ACEi given
   ARF, hypotension)
   Acute diastolic CHF: Potentially NSTEMI precipitated or infection, now
   likely clinically euvolemic. No RV pathology in recent ECHO from last
   week.
   - CXR overall unchanged.
   - Attempting to see if possible to concentrate medications to lessen
   IVF load.
   ARF: Resolved. Creatinine 1.1, from 1.3 yesterday, highest had been 1.4
   in setting of diuresis .
   - Will continue to follow trend.
   Heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan: Consider ultrasound to further
   characterize as outpatient.
   - TSH 0.51 on [**11-1**]
   DM2: FSBG have been running high since transfer up to 300-400. Suspect
   secondary to increased steroid dose, also possibly related to
   infection. FSBG was slightly low yesterday and this AM, so [**Month/Year (2) 3973**] was
   reduced to home dose of 20 units. Elevated insulin needs earlier in
   week may have been due to stress of transfer, possibly infection, but
   with increased steroid dose, this does not seen to be a problem
   currently.
   - [**Name2 (NI) **] and humalog sliding scale.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including diabetes, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and remains on 100% high-flow oxygen.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a blood pressure of 129/60 mmHg, heart rate of 64 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F). He has a central line and a peripheral intravenous line in place.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL, and leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 13.4 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests are slightly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 34 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 115 IU/L.

The patient has a history of hospital-acquired pneumonia and has been treated with empiric antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam. He has also received corticosteroids to treat possible exacerbation of his interstitial lung disease.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, piperacillin-tazobactam, and levofloxacin, as well as medications for his diabetes, heart failure, and other medical conditions.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation remains at 94%, which may indicate ongoing respiratory compromise. Further monitoring and potential intubation may be necessary.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of hospital-acquired pneumonia and is still receiving empiric antibiotics. Further cultures and monitoring for infection are necessary.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia is not fully understood, and further evaluation, including a complete blood count and reticulocyte count, may be necessary to determine the cause.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate ongoing infection or inflammation, and further evaluation, including a complete blood count and differential, may be necessary.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are slightly elevated, which may indicate ongoing liver dysfunction or injury. Further evaluation, including a liver function panel and imaging studies, may be necessary.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of heart failure and may be at risk for cardiovascular instability. Further monitoring and potential adjustments to his medications may be necessary.

In summary, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions, and ongoing monitoring and potential adjustments to his medications and treatment plan may be necessary to manage his condition and prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with worsening consolidation on chest x-ray, possible aspiration, and respiratory distress. They have received multiple antibiotics, including Bactrim, Piperacillin, Vancomycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam. The patient has a history of cardiac disease, diabetes, and is on medications for these conditions. They are currently receiving insulin for glycemic control, and their blood glucose levels are within a normal range.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 123/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 90%. Their respiratory rate is 18 inspirations per minute, and they are receiving high-flow oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin levels. Their liver function tests are within normal limits, and their kidney function tests show mild kidney injury. Their blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are elevated.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and worsening consolidation on chest x-ray increase the risk of respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and troponin levels suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac disease and elevated troponin levels increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.
4. Kidney injury: The patient's elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine levels suggest mild kidney injury, which can progress to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Liver injury: The patient's elevated liver enzymes suggest the possibility of liver injury, which can lead to liver failure or chronic liver disease.
6. Bloodstream infection: The patient's presence of central lines and urinary catheter increases the risk of bloodstream infection.
7. Pressure ulcers: The patient's immobility and prolonged stay in the ICU increase the risk of pressure ulcers.
8. ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
9. DVT: The patient's presence of central lines and immobility increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis.
10. Stress ulcer: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU and presence of central lines increase the risk of stress ulcer.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia and is currently receiving oxygen therapy. His respiratory status has worsened, with a chest x-ray showing possible consolidation and aspiration. He is being treated with empiric PCP, vancomycin, and zosyn for hospital-acquired pneumonia.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 8.4 g/dL and a platelet count of 375 K/uL. His white blood cell count is 13.4, and his liver function tests are slightly elevated. His creatinine level is stable at 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's medications include insulin, metoprolol, simvastatin, heparin, and methylprednisolone. He is also receiving oxygen therapy and nebulizer treatments as needed.

The patient's condition is complex, and potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he may require intubation and mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his hospital-acquired pneumonia and other underlying conditions.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and coronary artery disease, and may be at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, and he may require further transfusions.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are slightly elevated, and he may be at risk for liver dysfunction or failure.
6. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's creatinine level is stable, but he may be at risk for kidney dysfunction or failure.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and may be at risk for further bleeding or perforation.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his hospitalization and underlying conditions.

Based on this information, I recommend that the patient's care team continues to monitor his respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as needed. I also recommend that the team consider further diagnostic testing, such as a bronchoscopy or biospy, to help guide treatment and management of the patient's underlying conditions. Additionally, the team should continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust his medications as needed to manage his anemia, liver dysfunction, and kidney dysfunction.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Patient's Condition:**

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, interstitial lung disease, diastolic congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for hypoxia and has been experiencing persistent and slightly worsening hypoxia. The patient's oxygen requirement and breathing have not appreciably changed with pulse dose steroids.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Pneumonia:** The patient's chest x-ray shows possible worsening consolidation, which may indicate pneumonia. The patient's symptoms, such as shortness of breath and cough, are consistent with pneumonia.
2. **Aspiration:** The patient's history of diastolic congestive heart failure and recent diagnosis of unresectable cholangiocarcinoma increase his risk of aspiration.
3. **Cholangiocarcinoma progression:** The patient's cancer is unresectable, and there is a risk of progression and worsening respiratory status.
4. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia is stable but still unclear in etiology. Hemolysis, bactrim-related marrow suppression, or cancer-related anemia are potential causes.
5. **Hypotension:** The patient's hypotension has resolved, but there is a risk of recurrence, particularly with diuresis.
6. **Cholangio CA and biliary stricture:** The patient's cholangiocarcinoma and biliary stricture may lead to further complications, such as biliary obstruction or cholangitis.
7. **CAD/NSTEMI:** The patient's history of coronary artery disease and NSTEMI increases his risk of future cardiac events, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
8. **Acute diastolic CHF:** The patient's acute diastolic congestive heart failure may worsen if not managed appropriately.
9. **Thyroid heterogeneity:** The patient's heterogeneous thyroid on CT scan may require further evaluation with ultrasound.

**Plan:**

1. Continue empiric PCP treatment for 3 weeks.
2. Wean oxygen therapy to maintain saturation >90%.
3. Monitor stool guaiac for hemolysis.
4. Continue antifungal and antibiotic treatment for hospital-acquired pneumonia.
5. Monitor for signs of worsening respiratory status and adjust therapy accordingly.
6. Discuss goals of care and prognosis with the patient and his family.
7. Consider low-dose morphine or other agents to manage dyspnea.
8. Continue to monitor electrolytes and adjust therapy as needed.
9. Replete electrolytes as needed.
10. Discuss initiation of hepaticojejunostomy with the patient and his family.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure due to poorly characterized ILD, likely IPF or NSIP. He has a history of diastolic CHF, recent NSTEMI, and unresectable cholangiocarcinoma. His respiratory status has been gradually worsening over the past week, and he has been treated with pulse solumedrol for 3 days.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.4°F, heart rate of 61 bpm, blood pressure of 113/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95%. He is receiving nasal cannula oxygen and has a SpO2 of 95%. His respiratory support includes FiO2 of 6L NC and ABG of 27.

The patient's physical examination is notable for crackles in the lungs, with worsening consolidation or aspiration on CXR. He has a soft abdomen and no peripheral edema. His neurologic examination is normal, with interactive and a+o x 3.

Laboratory results show:

* WBC: 13.4-13.9 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 21.9-25.1%
* Plt: 329-375 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.1-1.3 mg/dL
* TropT: 0.02 ng/mL
* TCO2: 28 mmHg
* Glucose: 63-184 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin
* Statin
* Plavix
* Metoprolol
* Solumedrol
* Zosyn
* Vancomycin
* Heparin
* Prophylactic antibiotics

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Respiratory failure due to worsening ILD
* CHF exacerbation due to diastolic dysfunction
* CAD progression due to underlying coronary artery disease
* Elevated creatinine due to kidney dysfunction
* Anemia due to bleeding or bone marrow suppression
* DM due to insulin resistance or pancreatic dysfunction
* Cholangiocarcinoma progression due to unresectable disease
* DVT or PE due to immobility and anticoagulation
* VAP due to aspiration and respiratory support
* Stress ulcer due to critical illness and medication use

The patient's plan includes:

* Running a net negative fluid balance of 500 cc
* Starting inh NAC
* Continuing solumedrol through today and then changing to po prednisone
* Continuing zosyn/vanc for 3-4 days
* Considering bactrim for empiric PCP prophylaxis
* Continuing aspirin, statin, and plavix for CAD and CHF
* Monitoring creatinine and adjusting medication as necessary
* Monitoring anemia and adjusting transfusion as necessary
* Monitoring DM and adjusting insulin as necessary
* Continuing cholangiocarcinoma surveillance and management
* Continuing VAP and stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Continuing DVT and PE prophylaxis

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a complex medical history, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), recent non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), unresectable cholangiocarcinoma, and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

The patient's dyspnea has improved, but he is now experiencing worsening dyspnea when lying down. His SaO2 is in the mid-80s on nasal cannula (NC) and non-rebreather (NRB) mask. A chest X-ray (CXR) on November 7th showed worsening consolidation/aspiration.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and cardiovascular medications. He has also been receiving oxygen therapy and has been intubated.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.4-13.6 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 8.4-8.5 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 329-375 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.1-1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.7 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.1 g/dL
* LDH: 379 IU/L
* Calcium (Ca++): 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium (Mg++): 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate (PO4): 3.0 mg/dL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: likely due to ILD, poorly characterized, concern for IPF or NSIP
* CHF/CAD: diastolic CHF, recent NSTEMI, and CAD
* Elevated creatinine: at baseline
* Anemia: no clinical evidence of bleeding, responded well to transfusion
* DM: switched to NPH, will follow
* Cholangiocarcinoma: unresectable, but no evidence of distant spread

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure
* Renal failure or acute kidney injury
* Anemia or bleeding
* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
* Cholangitis or other complications related to the unresectable cholangiocarcinoma

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continuing respiratory support with oxygen therapy and possible intubation
* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure and adjusting treatment accordingly
* Managing CHF/CAD with medications and diuresis
* Monitoring creatinine and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Monitoring anemia and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Managing DM with insulin sliding scale
* Monitoring cholangiocarcinoma and adjusting treatment as necessary

The patient's ICU care plan includes:

* Aspiration precautions
* Glycemic control with regular insulin sliding scale
* Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Monitoring for signs of sepsis or septic shock

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent or treat potential medical complications.
